concept.title: Terminology, internal services, and concepts
concept.shortdesc: This section defines terminology, internal services that enable to function, and concepts that are used in this guide and other documentation.

dlentry.dd: One or more software services packaged in Docker containers.
A host that runs the application services scheduled for the resource pool to which it belongs. A system can be configured as delegate or master.

dlentry.dt: Docker Community Edition (Docker CE, or just Docker)
dlentry.dd: An open-source application for building, shipping, and running distributed applications.
( internal service) A distributed, real-time search and analytics engine. uses it to index log files and store service definitions.
( internal service) A browser-based user interface that enables the display and search of Elasticsearch databases, including the log files that monitors.
( internal service) A log file collector and aggregator that forwards parsed log file entries to Elasticsearch.

The host that runs the application services scheduler, the Docker registry, the distributed file system, and other internal services, including the HTTP server for the browser interface and application browser interface. A system can be configured as delegate or master. Only one host can be the master.
( internal service) A time series database that uses to store its service performance metrics.

A collection of one or more hosts, each with its own compute, network, and storage resources. All of the hosts in a resource pool must have identical hardware resources, and must be located in the same data center and on the same subnet. If a resource pool host is a hypervisor guest system, all of the hosts in the resource pool must be guests of the same hypervisor host system.
A process and its supporting files that runs in a single container to provide specific functionality as part of an application.
The name of the service and a command-line client for interacting with the service.
( internal service) A centralized service that uses for configuration maintenance, naming, distributed synchronization, and providing group services.
